articles.headline: Despite Climate Concerns, OPEC Plans to Keep Pumping Oil While It Can
articles.snippet: Some members, including the United Arab Emirates, have acknowledged that they need to diversify and wean themselves from an oil-rich diet.
articles.abstract: Some members, including the United Arab Emirates, have acknowledged that they need to diversify and wean themselves from an oil-rich diet.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — Even as United Nations climate-conference delegates met near Paris on Friday seeking ways to reduce the globe’s dependence on high-carbon fuels like oil, some of the world’s biggest petroleum producers vowed to keep pumping flat out.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Sara Hamdan

articles.headline: Russian Truckers, Irate Over New Tolls, Block Roads Near Moscow
articles.snippet: The truck drivers unhappy about new tolls and the economy are the kind of bedrock Russians for whom Vladimir V. Putin has long been a hero.
articles.abstract: The truck drivers unhappy about new tolls and the economy are the kind of bedrock Russians for whom Vladimir V. Putin has long been a hero.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Hundreds of long-distance truckers blocked a lengthy section of the ring road circling the capital on Friday to protest a new national toll, in the first sign that Russia’s economic woes might be eroding the broad support for President Vladimir V. Putin’s government.

articles.headline: The End of Social Security Loopholes: What Now?
articles.snippet: Advice on when it’s best to file for benefits depends on several factors, but generally, it’s best to wait as long as you can, advisers say.
articles.abstract: Advice on when it’s best to file for benefits depends on several factors, but generally, it’s best to wait as long as you can, advisers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, retirees have been able to squeeze tens of thousands of extra dollars from Social Security using two special tactics. Though they went by gimmicky names like “claim benefits now, claim more later,” these strategies were perfectly legal.

articles.headline: China Creates a World Bank of Its Own, and the U.S. Balks
articles.snippet: In setting up the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, China enlisted American allies, including Britain, even as Washington expressed skepticism.
articles.abstract: In setting up the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, China enlisted American allies, including Britain, even as Washington expressed skepticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As top leaders met at a lush Bali resort in October 2013, President Xi Jinping of China described his vision for a new multinational, multibillion-dollar bank to finance roads, rails and power grids across Asia. Under Chinese stewardship, the bank would tackle the slow development in poor countries that was holding the region back from becoming the wealth center of the world.

articles.headline: Wally Lamb’s Latest Novel to Be Released Exclusively as Book App
articles.snippet: The book, “I’ll Take You There,” will be published by Metabook, with multimedia components such as a full cast audio drama.
articles.abstract: The book, “I’ll Take You There,” will be published by Metabook, with multimedia components such as a full cast audio drama.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1992, two debut novelists gave a joint reading at a Manhattan bookstore. One of them was Ken Siman, whose novel, “Pizza Face,” sold decently, but was hardly a blockbuster. He eventually went on to pursue a career in publishing.

articles.headline: Gad Elmaleh: Talking Funny in French and English
articles.snippet: The Moroccan-born French comedian often called the Jerry Seinfeld of France is hoping for success here as well.
articles.abstract: The Moroccan-born French comedian often called the Jerry Seinfeld of France is hoping for success here as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: As stand-up comedy becomes an increasingly global phenomenon, international stars are starting to emerge, like the South African Trevor Noah, who played to huge audiences in Africa before taking over “The Daily Show.” Now Gad Elmaleh, a Moroccan-born stand-up comedian often called the Jerry Seinfeld of France, is hoping for crossover success here as well. He’s embarking on his first significant run of shows in English beginning Sunday at Joe’s Pub, part of a national tour and later New York residency.

articles.headline: Draghi Says No Limits on European Stimulus Measures
articles.snippet: Markets fell sharply on Thursday, on concern the European Central Bank’s stimulus package was not stronger. On Friday, Mario Draghi said there would be “no particular limit” to the bank’s efforts.
articles.abstract: Markets fell sharply on Thursday, on concern the European Central Bank’s stimulus package was not stronger. On Friday, Mario Draghi said there would be “no particular limit” to the bank’s efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a speech to Wall Street investors, the president of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, reinforced his promise to do all in his power to push Europe’s stagnating economy toward a full recovery.

articles.headline: Fed Might Not Have the Luxury of Slow and Steady Rate Increases
articles.snippet: Despite signals that the Fed will raise rates gradually, three factors could prompt the bank to move more quickly than investors would like, one analyst says.
articles.abstract: Despite signals that the Fed will raise rates gradually, three factors could prompt the bank to move more quickly than investors would like, one analyst says.
articles.lead_paragraph: After seven years of keeping United States interest rates at rock bottom, the Federal Reserve has signaled that Dec. 16 could be D-Day for a long-awaited increase. That was the message Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, conveyed in two public presentations last week.

articles.headline: After San Bernardino Attack, Republican Candidates Talk ‘War’
articles.snippet: As Republican candidates demanded on Friday that the United States face up to a new world war, Democrats seemed to offer a more muddled response.
articles.abstract: As Republican candidates demanded on Friday that the United States face up to a new world war, Democrats seemed to offer a more muddled response.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican candidates for president angrily demanded on Friday that the United States face up to a new world war, one that has breached its borders, threatened the safety of Americans and brought the menace of Islamic terrorism deep into the homeland.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro and Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Nigeria’s Comics Pull Punch Lines From Deeper Social Ills
articles.snippet: In a nation troubled by corruption, blackouts and the scourge of Boko Haram, stand-up comics are mining the misery for laughs and are more popular than ever.
articles.abstract: In a nation troubled by corruption, blackouts and the scourge of Boko Haram, stand-up comics are mining the misery for laughs and are more popular than ever.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — The thieves were having a field day, the comedian Ali Baba exclaimed to a large auditorium of lawyers. It was so bad that they struck every car along a deeply potholed road — that is, until a former governor came along.

articles.headline: Martin Shkreli, the Bad Boy of Pharmaceuticals, Hits Back
articles.snippet: The chief of Turing Pharmaceuticals, who increased a drug’s price to $750 from $13.50 a pill, has been bashed as the face of corporate greed. But he’s still smiling.
articles.abstract: The chief of Turing Pharmaceuticals, who increased a drug’s price to $750 from $13.50 a pill, has been bashed as the face of corporate greed. But he’s still smiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli was trying to explain himself, so he turned to YouTube.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Andrew Pollack

articles.headline: 95,000 Words, Many of Them Ominous, From Donald Trump’s Tongue
articles.snippet: An analysis of 95,000 words Mr. Trump said in public in the past week reveals powerful patterns in his speech which, historians say, echo the appeals of demagogues of the past century.
articles.abstract: An analysis of 95,000 words Mr. Trump said in public in the past week reveals powerful patterns in his speech which, historians say, echo the appeals of demagogues of the past century.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Something bad is happening,” Donald J. Trump warned New Hampshire voters Tuesday night, casting suspicions on Muslims and mosques. “Something really dangerous is going on.”
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: For San Bernardino Survivors, a Day of Screams and Chaos
articles.snippet: Those who emerged after the methodical assault at the Inland Regional Center recall a mix of training and holiday celebrating suddenly gone wrong.
articles.abstract: Those who emerged after the methodical assault at the Inland Regional Center recall a mix of training and holiday celebrating suddenly gone wrong.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — The noise was deafening. The blast of gunshots. The piercing shriek of a fire alarm, and the torrent of water gushing from the sprinkler system, mixing with the blood on the floor.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Jennifer Medina, Ian Lovett and Julie Turkewitz

articles.headline: In Nigeria, Chinese Investment Comes With a Downside
articles.snippet: Like other developing countries, Nigeria has welcomed Chinese trade, but that relationship has left the country awash in shoddy imported goods and has cost many Nigerians their jobs.
articles.abstract: Like other developing countries, Nigeria has welcomed Chinese trade, but that relationship has left the country awash in shoddy imported goods and has cost many Nigerians their jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Emeka Ezelugha was excited to open a computer training center. He could teach his countrymen some skills and earn a living.
articles.byline: By Keith Bradsher and Adam Nossiter

articles.headline: California Attack Has U.S. Rethinking Strategy on Homegrown Terror
articles.snippet: On Sunday, President Obama will address the nation on the broad threat of terrorism, while providing updates on the investigation into the attack in San Bernardino, Calif.
articles.abstract: On Sunday, President Obama will address the nation on the broad threat of terrorism, while providing updates on the investigation into the attack in San Bernardino, Calif.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day before Thanksgiving, President Obama reassured Americans there was “no specific and credible intelligence indicating a plot on the homeland.” Seven days later came an explosion of gunfire and the deadliest terrorist attack in America since Sept. 11, 2001.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Meal Plan Costs Tick Upward as Students Pay for More Than Food
articles.snippet: Universities are embracing lucrative deals with dining contractors to help pay for campus improvements, but critics say students often pay for them in the rising costs of meal plans.
articles.abstract: Universities are embracing lucrative deals with dining contractors to help pay for campus improvements, but critics say students often pay for them in the rising costs of meal plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — Before his 35-mile commute through Appalachian hills to classes here at the University of Tennessee, Michael Miceli eats a gigantic breakfast. It is his way of getting through the day without spending money on a campus lunch.

articles.headline: Marco Rubio, Switching Focus, Aims to Halt Ted Cruz’s Momentum
articles.snippet: In interviews, speeches and in stealthier ways, Mr. Rubio has abruptly changed the course of his campaign to zero in on Mr. Cruz and reverse his gains among conservative voters.
articles.abstract: In interviews, speeches and in stealthier ways, Mr. Rubio has abruptly changed the course of his campaign to zero in on Mr. Cruz and reverse his gains among conservative voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: VAN HORNE, Iowa — For months, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida ran an above-the-fray presidential race, high-mindedly dismissing his Republican rivals’ attacks and promising a campaign his family could be proud of long after 2016.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: X Marks the Spot That Makes Online Ads So Maddening
articles.snippet: They pop up, they expand, they take over, they even dance: As our screens have shrunk, online advertisements have grown ever more annoying.
articles.abstract: They pop up, they expand, they take over, they even dance: As our screens have shrunk, online advertisements have grown ever more annoying.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ads pop up and play automatically, daring readers to shut them down with feats of fine motor control. The ads commandeer the screen. They expand and contract. They cover the text and refuse to budge.

articles.headline: ‘Unboxing’ Videos a Gift to Marketers
articles.snippet: YouTube says that this year people have watched videos unveiling items like toys and iPhones more than 1.1 billion times, for a total of 60 million hours.
articles.abstract: YouTube says that this year people have watched videos unveiling items like toys and iPhones more than 1.1 billion times, for a total of 60 million hours.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day last year, Jessica Nelson was surprised to find her toddler, Aiden, watching videos online in which people opened box after box of new toys, from Kinder Surprise chocolate eggs with trinkets inside to all manner of Disney merchandise.

articles.headline: Sarcasm and Doubt Precede VW’s Update on Cheating Inquiry
articles.snippet: There is concern about the German government’s reluctance to take on a company that is a symbol of the nation’s economic success.
articles.abstract: There is concern about the German government’s reluctance to take on a company that is a symbol of the nation’s economic success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOLFSBURG, Germany — With Volkswagen’s emissions-cheating scandal nearing an important milestone — the chief executive this week is expected to deliver his first public update on VW’s internal investigation — some critics doubt Germany’s willingness to be tough on the automaker.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Graham Bowley and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Obama Says of Terrorist Threat: ‘We Will Overcome It’
articles.snippet: In a prime-time address, President Obama bluntly acknowledged heightened worries after the attacks in Paris and in San Bernardino, Calif., and urged Americans not to give in to fear.
articles.abstract: In a prime-time address, President Obama bluntly acknowledged heightened worries after the attacks in Paris and in San Bernardino, Calif., and urged Americans not to give in to fear.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama sought on Sunday to calm jittery Americans after the terrorist attack last week in California, delivering a prime-time address designed to underscore the government’s campaign against an evolving threat.
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Tashfeen Malik Was a ‘Saudi Girl’ Who Stood Out at a Pakistani University
articles.snippet: Teachers remember Ms. Malik, who was born in Pakistan but spent most of her life in Saudi Arabia, as a polite and driven student. But the timing and circumstances of her shift into militancy remain a mystery.
articles.abstract: Teachers remember Ms. Malik, who was born in Pakistan but spent most of her life in Saudi Arabia, as a polite and driven student. But the timing and circumstances of her shift into militancy remain a mystery.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — As a tide of Islamist violence washed across Pakistan in recent years, Bahauddin Zakariya University in the southern city of Multan struggled to halt spreading intolerance, with mixed results.

articles.headline: San Bernardino Community Struck by Massacre Seemed on Verge of Turnaround
articles.snippet: The terrorist attack was another blow for this downtrodden working-class city an hour outside Los Angeles, and just at a moment when things seemed to have been improving.
articles.abstract: The terrorist attack was another blow for this downtrodden working-class city an hour outside Los Angeles, and just at a moment when things seemed to have been improving.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — Erika Flores knows this city’s struggles, and she knows its reputation. She has lived here for five years. Five years pummeled by bankruptcy. A recall aimed at its elected city officials. Gangs, crime, high unemployment and recession.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney, Ian Lovett and Rick Rojas

articles.headline: A Revolving Door Helps Big Banks’ Quiet Campaign to Muscle Out Fannie and Freddie
articles.snippet: A behind-the-scenes effort of Wall Street banks to take over the mortgage market is driven by advocates who switch between roles in Washington and the private sector.
articles.abstract: A behind-the-scenes effort of Wall Street banks to take over the mortgage market is driven by advocates who switch between roles in Washington and the private sector.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seven years after their dubious lending practices helped push the United States economy to the brink of disaster, the nation’s largest banks are closing in on a long-sought goal: to unseat Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the mortgage finance giants, and capture their share of the profits in the country’s $5.7 trillion home loan market.

articles.headline: Keurig Added to Coffee Empire of European Investor Group
articles.snippet: The Reimann family of Germany is on a caffeine-fueled binge to roll up the coffee industry, with the $13.9 billion deal for Keurig Green Mountain.
articles.abstract: The Reimann family of Germany is on a caffeine-fueled binge to roll up the coffee industry, with the $13.9 billion deal for Keurig Green Mountain.
articles.lead_paragraph: A billionaire European family is on a caffeine-fueled binge to roll up the global coffee industry, with a huge bet announced Monday: a $13.9 billion acquisition of Keurig Green Mountain.
articles.byline: By Leslie Picker and Stephanie Strom
